title: Phrack World News - Issue XXI/2
historical_context: This issue of Phrack captures a pivotal moment in the late 1980s when computer viruses and hacking were becoming more prominent in public consciousness, leading to legal repercussions.
short_summary: This issue covers various incidents involving computer viruses, legal cases against hackers, and notable events in the hacker community, reflecting the evolving landscape of computer security and hacking culture.
summary:
In this edition of Phrack, the focus is on the burgeoning issues surrounding computer viruses and the legal ramifications for hackers. The article discusses the case of Donald Gene Burleson, who was charged with infecting his former employer's computers with a virus that deleted over 168,000 records. This case marked a significant moment in legal history as it was one of the first prosecutions under a new law against computer sabotage. The article highlights the serious consequences of hacking, as Burleson faced up to 10 years in prison if convicted, illustrating the growing concern over computer security in the late 1980s.

Additionally, the issue includes various anecdotes from the hacker community, such as the story of a teenager who racked up a massive phone bill through blue boxing, and the exposure of an imposter claiming to be a well-known hacker. These narratives not only showcase the creativity and audacity of hackers but also serve as cautionary tales about the risks involved in hacking activities. The blend of legal news and community stories provides a comprehensive snapshot of the hacker culture during this transformative period in technology.
